item.title: wordpress-importer.patch attached to Ticket #11354
item.dc:creator: briancolinger
item.description: patch for process_categories() and process_tags() methods

item.title: Ticket #11354 (WordPress Importer duplicates categories) created
item.dc:creator: briancolinger
item.description:
The WordPress importer duplicates categories. This only seems to affect child categories. To reproduce, get an export file that has parent and children categories. Run the importer multiple times with the same file. View the category screen under Posts->Categories, you should see duplicated child categories.

I've included a patch for the process_categories() method that fixes this by explicitly checking if each category_exists(). I've included the same patch for process_tags() method. Tags do not duplicate, but wp_insert_term() is called without checking if the tag exists.

item.title: Ticket #8841 (Threaded comments display out of order if conditions are met.) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
Replying to voyagerfan5761:

The first comment and the second comment are switched. The IDs and timestamps are correct, but they're being sorted out of any logical order. Blogger doesn't have threaded comments, either, and I have threaded comments in WP turned off.

yours is a separate issue which comes from the importer, and which should be fixed (for the most part anyway) in 2.9.

item.title: Ticket #8841 (Threaded comments display out of order if conditions are met.) updated
item.dc:creator: voyagerfan5761
item.description:
Cc changed

I don't know if my issue is the same, but I'm using WP 2.8.6 and having a comment-ordering issue with one of my posts. There are only a few comments, but the whole shebang was imported from Blogger using the built-in tool. See the problem page at â€‹http://technobabbl.es/2008/06/two-types-of-friends-found-poem/

The first comment and the second comment are switched. The IDs and timestamps are correct, but they're being sorted out of any logical order. Blogger doesn't have threaded comments, either, and I have threaded comments in WP turned off.

item.title: Ticket #11353 (Edit User always refers to "your username" even when editing another user) created
item.dc:creator: caesarsgrunt
item.description:
When editing a user, it always says "Your username cannot be changed" next to the username field, even if it is not yourself that you are editing.

It should not mention you if you are not editing yourself. Instead it should say something like "This user's username cannot be changed", or just say "Username cannot be changed" for all users.

item.title: Ticket #9864 (Performance issues with large number of pages) updated
item.dc:creator: prettyboymp
item.description:
What if the functionality of this metabox just degraded nicer? We could add some handling that said if the number of pages were over say 200, then instead of doing the normal drop down box, we use pop up style selector similar to the way the media_upload browser is used for the post image handling.

This would allow smaller sites to continue to make quick and easy selection like they do now while keeping it from breaking completely for larger sites.

That sounds like a plan -- though this patch will need some more work now as it's quite old and merging it into the current trunk is a big job (we gave up).

(Unless, of course prettyboymp has already done that in the fixed version?)

The latest patch is from HEAD as of this morning.

@markjaquith -- I'd like to suggest that we go ahead and make generic handlers (functions/classes) for all of the ones that are currently category taxonomy specific and just make the category specific functions use those. This would also include wp-admin/categories.php and the Walker_Category. I have no problem adding additional patches (probably under a new ticket) for these as long as it fits the roadmap.

item.description: The delete button does not work as expected in Internet Explorer and Firefox. It works as expected in Safari and Chrome. There is no reliable way for TinyMCE or WordPress to fix these browser bugs, so I think they should be reported to the browser vendors and this ticked closed.

item.title: Ticket #10122 (create metaboxes for hierarchical taxonomies) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Milestone changed

Replying to harrym:

@ryan -- Any particular reason this isn't going to make it into 2.9? Is there anything a willing volunteer could do to help?

We were in beta by then, and are in beta 2 now. Unfortunately, it's just too late. But I really like this idea, so don't give up â€” let's work on getting this finished and in, early in the 3.0 cycle. We should be branching soon.

As part of this, we should consider redoing our default post categories widget to use this code.

item.title: Ticket #11203 (Missing check for action type) reopened
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description: This was reverted in [12330] for #11351 as this change broke functionality.

item.title: Ticket #10379 ("Remove" in widgets should read: "Delete") updated
item.dc:creator: janeforshort
item.description:
Type changed

Contextually, remove means "remove from sidebar" and should probably move it to inactive area. From inactive area, "Remove" should be "Delete" instead, since you're deleting the formatted/configured widget. We should get rid of the current method of deleting by dragging back to the Available Widgets area, as it implies the configured widget is being moved, not that it's being deleted. And changing "Remove" to "Deactivate" when in the sidebar sounds good to me in terms of being like the language used for plugins, but Remove also refers to the location (remove from sidebar), which I like.

I think for now making Remove be Delete in the Inactive widget area, and having Remove while in a sidebar initiate a move to Inactive Widgets area is the simplest thing to do, and we can refine it more maybe after some testing.

item.title: Ticket #11338 (Custom Walker initialize error) updated
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
Replying to dd32:

Because its invalid PHP.

for a start: $walker_category = new Walker_Category_Rabbit() - parenthesis on the end.

I'm pretty sure parentheses are optional, although I can't find any official documentation that says one way or the other. I've never seen any syntax warnings when omitting them, most PHP books I've read omit them frequently, and even â€‹this PHP manual example of object instantiation omits them.

However, I'd certainly be interested in seeing any contradicting documentation you can point me to.

item.title: Ticket #11350 (Post tags (wp-admin/edit-tags.php) doesn't work without JavaScript) updated
item.dc:creator: janeforshort
item.description:
Component changed

There should be a non-JS version that triggers a screen refresh when you click the Add Tag button. I just disabled JS on OSX/FF3 to see what happens, and it refreshed the screen on submit but didn't add the new tag to the table. Definitely a bug. Changing component to accessibility because having non-JS methods of performing tasks is an accessibility requirement.

I agree that that is a good idea, but since the behavior in 2.8 (when it was a Delete link appearing rather than a Trash link) worked this way, asking to change it is a feature request, and too late for 2.9. I'd like to see this get in early in 3.0, though. For 2.9 people will just do the same thing they've been doing in this situation.

item.title: Ticket #10619 (Importing WXR breaks serialized postmeta value) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
Keywords, Owner, Status changed

I think znafor's patch is the best solution here.

On export we put the raw data from the db into the xml file.

Normally when getting the post meta we would have called maybe_unserialize on the value before returning - therefore we should replicate that here before passing to add post meta so that we have the same consistent behaviour.

Could someone generate a small WXR file with some post meta in to test this with and report back on sucess/failure

item.title: Ticket #11352 (Empty all Trashes from Tools) updated
item.dc:creator: caesarsgrunt
item.description: Oops. Sorry about the formatting. Pity Trac won't let non-admins edit their own tickets... :-(

item.title: Ticket #11352 (Empty all Trashes from Tools) created
item.dc:creator: caesarsgrunt
item.description:
A possible enhancement for 3.0 (too late for 2.9 now).

EITHER Add an Empty All Trashes button to the Tools page.

OR Add an Empty Trash button with checkboxes which would allow you to choose one or more Trash to empty.

I'm not necessarily saying I think we should do either of these; it's just a concept.

item.title: Ticket #11351 (Trash link should appear after autosave) created
item.dc:creator: caesarsgrunt
item.description:
I start writing a post. After the first couple of paragraphs I decide to delete what I have done. I haven't saved yet.

To delete the draft post, I have to go to the Posts list and click Trash, because the Trash link on the edit page doesn't appear until after I have manually saved the page.

The Trash link should appear after the first autosave.

item.title: Ticket #11349 (Control+Shift+Z (Redo) Increases Font of Both TinyMCE and GUI) closed
item.dc:creator: caesarsgrunt
item.description:
invalid:

Although this is highly irritating, the fault lies in Firefox rather than WordPress.

Go to google.com and press ctrl+shift+z - the same will happen.

It might be possible to override this by capturing the keys on the page, though I don't know if we should override browser shortcuts even if they are the most irritating 'features' ever.

item.title: Ticket #11350 (Post tags (wp-admin/edit-tags.php) doesn't work without JavaScript) updated
item.dc:creator: dd32
item.description:
Keywords, Version, Component, Milestone changed

Current "correct" behaviour would be for the add tags button to be hidden.

Current expected behaviour is that multiple tags would be seperated with commas within the tags field if JS was unavailable.

(AFAIK)

item.title: Ticket #11350 (Post tags (wp-admin/edit-tags.php) doesn't work without JavaScript) created
item.dc:creator: holizz
item.description: Given JavaScript is disabled And I am on the post tags page Then I fill in "Tag name" with "testing" And I press "Add Tag" Then I should see "testing" within the table of tags

item.title: wpblowup.gif attached to Ticket #11349
item.dc:creator: Coen Naninck

item.title: Ticket #11349 (Control+Shift+Z (Redo) Increases Font of Both TinyMCE and GUI) created
item.dc:creator: Coen Naninck
item.description:
I couldn't find this thing already listed, so hopefully this isn't a duplicate. Although I'm curious why no one has reported on it yet, if nobody actually has.

This 'issue' causes WordPress to blow up the font when invoking the Redo function in the TinyMCE. I know Control+Y is the default Redo funtion (as opposed to Control+Z for Undo), but many applications today still use Control+Shift+Z to Redo. Regardless of that, I think the behavior that it shows is wrong nonetheless, because both the TinyMCE as well as the Graphical User Interface are affected by invoking this shortcut. Note that when switching to HTML view the font size has actually been increased as well. And unfortunately, this action CANNOT be undone (or undo'd w/e). See the attached screen capture for clues.

item.title: Ticket #11286 (Normal User Input Causes Status 500) updated
item.dc:creator: dd32
item.description:
In between beta and release there is usually a part where all the known bugs get fixed. Fix it or close it. Punting these things is a waste of everyone's time.

In WordPress that period is usually reserves for major bugs, and those which are regressions from the previous version, This is in order to attempt to make sure the final release does not work worse than the previous.

Due to this being a change in the output behaviour of WordPress, It should be dealt with during the development period.

I'm not saying this is the absolute best proceedure, I am mearly stating that this is how its currently done. The next release of WordPress is only just around the corner, The core developers are focusing only on show-stopping regressions. This is not a regression from 2.8.x

item.title: Ticket #10619 (Importing WXR breaks serialized postmeta value) updated
item.dc:creator: znarfor
item.description:
Cc, Keywords changed

Actually, I think westi was right, we just need to unserialize the data before importing it. My patch above simply does this.

item.title: unserialize.import.diff attached to Ticket #10619
item.dc:creator: znarfor
item.description: Alternative patch

item.title: Ticket #11348 (Archive Page Should be 404.php When !have_posts()) closed
item.dc:creator: greenshady
item.description:
invalid:

It shouldn't be a 404. What's displayed on this page should be handled by the theme's category.php file. Just because something doesn't have posts, doesn't mean it's an invalid URL.

WordPress will also link to a category without posts using:

wp_list_categories( array( 'hide_empty' => false ) );

I'm going to mark this one as invalid unless others think this needs more discussion.

item.title: Ticket #10619 (Importing WXR breaks serialized postmeta value) updated
item.dc:creator: beaulebens
item.description:
Cc changed

I have to agree with johncoswell here, I think if something is passed to maybe_serialize which is already serialized, then the answer should be "don't serialize (again)" and the already-serialized value should be sent back.

item.title: Ticket #10391 (Fishy looking comment_agents in the livejournal importer) closed
item.dc:creator: beaulebens
item.description:
invalid:

Those are intentional. They are required to maintain and manipulate the threading of comments during import, and everything is cleaned up towards the end of the importer.

This could all potentially be rewritten to use the new commentmeta table in 2.9 though if someone was interested.

item.title: Ticket #11212 (Add filter to wp_parse_args()) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
Replying to westi:

If the filter was specific to the function being called that would be much more sensible - e.g. wp_parse_args_function_name

Silly me. That makes a lot more sense. *facepalm*

item.description: Reverting [12324] and [12322] after some discussion.

item.title: Ticket #11338 (Custom Walker initialize error) updated
item.dc:creator: dd32
item.description:
and it kills the blog. I am figuring out what is going on.

Because its invalid PHP.

for a start: $walker_category = new Walker_Category_Rabbit() - parenthesis on the end.

Secondly, You cannot convert a object to a string and expect it to work - Only use the array format if at all possible, infact, only the array format will work when passing objects.

item.title: Ticket #11348 (Archive Page Should be 404.php When !have_posts()) updated
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description: I don't think a 404 response is appropriate for an existing but empty category. According to the HTTP protocol, a 404 means "The server has not found anything matching the Request-URI." But in the case of an empty category, it has found something: that URI corresponds to the requested category.

item.title: Ticket #11348 (Archive Page Should be 404.php When !have_posts()) created
item.dc:creator: miqrogroove
item.description:
When categories are empty, WordPress does not link to /category/iamempty/ anywhere I can think of. Yet if you hit an empty category URL directly, WordPress fails to forward to the 404 page.

See also â€‹http://wordpress.org/support/topic/322407

item.title: Ticket #11338 (Custom Walker initialize error) reopened
item.dc:creator: ShaneF
item.description:
Nevermind. There is an error. I now have this: 

$walker_category = new Walker_Category_Rabbit;
		// array('title_li' => '', 'orderby' => 'name', 'show_count' => 1, 'feed' => 'RSS', 'depth' => -1, 'echo' => 0, 'walker' => $walker_category)
		$category_args = array('title_li=&orderby=name&show_count=1&feed=RSS&depth=-1&echo=0&walker='.$walker_category);

and it kills the blog. I am figuring out what is going on.

item.title: Ticket #11139 (minor trackback_rdf() fix) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
We removed the calls to this in the default/classic themes back in 1.5.x in [2417].

I think we can just deprecate the functions - and they can return nothing as we use the rel="trackback" method for discovery.

item.title: Ticket #11325 (Image cropping doesn't work for small areas) updated
item.dc:creator: janeforshort
item.description:
Discussing with Andrew, Mark, Ryan and Peter IRL right now. Popular opinion seems to be that it's generally reasonable to have a minimum size. Potential cases where it would be useful to go smaller would be if you want to insert little accent images like icons or something, but this seems a bit edge case to delay a release for since there's no patch. Moving to 3.0 with intention of addressing earlyish.

Note: Please do not change back to 2.9 unless a) there's a use case in which this is a blocker that we are missing, and b) there is a patch, since we are already in Beta 2.

item.title: Ticket #11286 (Normal User Input Causes Status 500) updated

Moving to 3.0

This has always been the case; it was only recently that I noticed that it didn't happen on my local testing server!

Both sites are 2.9 beta 2.

Priority, Milestone changed

Your patch won't leave out the string. It just will disable its translation.

If you really want to remove the string, you have to patch wp_timezone_choice().

I don't see the point in removing old names of cities. Is it really important? Aren't there any people who know it under its old name?

item.dc:creator: amattie
item.description:
Replying to dd32:

I've got a IIS7.5 install here, But cannot get it to return compressed content to WordPress no matter how hard i try, Other browsers are OK, but just not WP, even with the proper deflate, gzip and compress Accept headers set. - For now i'll have to give up trying to debug this one.

I found a production IIS 7 server that we can use for the purposes of debugging this issue. I'll have it up w/in a day and post back here once it's ready.

item.title: Ticket #11212 (Add filter to wp_parse_args()) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
sorry... I was misinterpreting what the two of you had written. it seemed to me that the difference between: 

$args = wp_parse_args($args, $defaults, 'foobar'); // applies wp_parse_args-foobar filter to the result

and: 

$args = wp_parse_args($args, $defaults);
$args = apply_filters('foobar', $args);

went down to the second being less CPU intensive.

item.title: Ticket #11269 (Media page jumps after unfolding image details) updated
item.dc:creator: caesarsgrunt
item.description: Jane, I know scribu only said he tested it in FF 3.5 - but myself, if I recall correctly, I tested it in Firefox 3.5, Safari 4, Opera 10, and IE 8 before uploading the patch. I do this for most patches to client-side code.

item.title: Ticket #11212 (Add filter to wp_parse_args()) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
I'm not a big fan of this.

I think that is is better to have targeted filters which are much safer for plugins to use.

If we add this filter every thing that is hooked on to it is going to have to check the context which is a really bad idea.

The more specifically targeted a filter the better.

If the filter was specific to the function being called that would be much more sensible - e.g. wp_parse_args_function_name

item.title: Ticket #11276 (Wrong default upload directory) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: upload_url_path is not adjusted to accommodate safe mode the way upload_path is. Since safe_mode breaking mkdir() doesn't seem to be particularly true, let's just drop that check and always default upload_path and upload_url_path to blank.

item.title: Ticket #10337 (Easier embeds for 2.9 (oEmbed perhaps?)) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description: Two new patches. One switches DailyMotion support from a hard-coded handler to oEmbed. The other ditches the usage of the object cache as it can't be expected to never expire (we don't want caching without the blog owner's knowledge) and there's also no easy way to clear out the oEmbed cache for a post. Better to just stick to using the post meta.

item.title: 10337.12.patch attached to Ticket #10337
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description: Don't use the object cache. We can't be sure it won't expire and that will require re-caching on a page load (that's bad). Always use post meta API (it has it's own object caching). Also use better cache key.

item.title: Ticket #11343 (Allow echo or return of 'posts_nav_link') updated
item.dc:creator: dd32
item.description:
-1 IMO: template functions should stay as template functions, If you need to check for the existance of something in there, the get_*() variety of functions should be used, else its just duplicating functions..

Some of the other similar functions from that era have the bool, but i'm pretty sure that is because there was no get_*() style functions then?

item.title: posts_nav_link.diff attached to Ticket #11343
item.dc:creator: ShaneF

item.title: Ticket #11343 (Allow echo or return of 'posts_nav_link') created
item.dc:creator: ShaneF
item.description: Right now the only option you are forced to use is 'echo'. This patch allows you to return the output. This way you can test to see if it is empty or not. Good for formatting.

item.title: Ticket #11342 (Allow echo or return of 'posts_nav_link') created
item.dc:creator: ShaneF
item.description: Right now the only option you are forced to use is 'echo'. This patch allows you to return the output. This way you can test to see if it is empty or not. Good for formating.

item.title: Ticket #10326 (strip_shortcodes() greedily strips surrounding bytes) updated
item.dc:creator: miqrogroove
item.description:
Severity changed

Increase severity because this bug is causing UTF-8 corruption and Google was rejecting my feeds until I applied this patch.

item.title: Ticket #11311 (kses converts ampersands to & in post titles, post content, and more) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description: wp_kses_normalize_entities() (called by wp_kses() which is called by wp_filter_kses()) causes this.

item.title: Ticket #11341 (Reproducible Feed Failure) updated
item.dc:creator: miqrogroove
item.description:
Steps to reproduce:

  1. Publish this in a new post (HTML view for consistency): 
[gallery orderby="title"]å½¢
  1. Hit your feed with everything you've got. â€‹http://validator.w3.org/feed/

Expected result: 

(HT,HT)<description><![CDATA[(E5,BD,A2)(LF)
]]></description>(LF)
(HT,HT,HT)<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>(E5,BD,A2)</p>(LF)
]]></content:encoded>(LF)

Actual result: 

(HT,HT)<description><![CDATA[(BD,A2)(LF)
]]></description>(LF)
(HT,HT,HT)<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>(E5,BD,A2)</p>(LF)
]]></content:encoded>(LF)

item.title: Ticket #11341 (Reproducible Feed Failure) created
item.dc:creator: miqrogroove
item.description:
I found a neat one. Google just rejected one of my feeds due to UTF-8 corruption. Everything looks perfect in the back end, the editor, the post itself, and with plugins turned off.

I'll attach a test case shortly.

item.title: Ticket #11316 (Deflate decompression error with PHP 5.3.0 and IIS 7) updated
item.dc:creator: miqrogroove
item.description: Many of them were HEAD requests back to my site. Anyway, it looks I would need a proper try/catch hack to get something useful out of this.

item.title: Ticket #11316 (Deflate decompression error with PHP 5.3.0 and IIS 7) updated
item.dc:creator: dd32
item.description:
What on earth is your server making hundreds of requests to? Sounds like you've got something worse to worry about to me..

I've got a IIS7.5 install here, But cannot get it to return compressed content to WordPress no matter how hard i try, Other browsers are OK, but just not WP, even with the proper deflate, gzip and compress Accept headers set. - For now i'll have to give up trying to debug this one.

item.title: Ticket #11316 (Deflate decompression error with PHP 5.3.0 and IIS 7) updated
item.dc:creator: miqrogroove
item.description: oh now I see I'm deleting progressively older entries. Sorry but this is no good. My server made several hundred requests at the time of the error.

item.title: Ticket #11286 (Normal User Input Causes Status 500) updated
item.dc:creator: solarissmoke
item.description:
Cc changed

Replying to miqrogroove:

With regard to your proposed patch, you also need to modify wp-includes/comments.php, because that is where duplicate comments are checked. Amendment attached.

item.title: Ticket #11316 (Deflate decompression error with PHP 5.3.0 and IIS 7) updated
item.dc:creator: dd32
item.description:
All I have is the error log. Where do I find this other server?

You need to know what is calling wp_remote_get() and what URL its fetching.

You can try installing my Core Control plugin (â€‹http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/core-control/) and enabling the outgoing HTTP Logger, That may give you some explanation on it.
